Antibiotic wastewater poses significant environmental risks due to the persistent micropollutants such as tetracycline (TC), which contribute to the development of antibiotic resistance. In this study, cobalt-doped molybdenum disulfide (Co-MoS₂) catalysts were synthesized via the hydrothermal method to enhance peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation for efficient TC degradation. Comprehensive material characterizations (XRD, FT-IR, SEM, XPS) confirmed the successful incorporation of Co into the MoS2 lattice, resulting in a mesoporous structure with an increased specific surface area, improved charge transfer efficiency, and greater exposure of active sites. Under optimal conditions, the 3.0%Co-MoS₂ catalyst achieved 81.5% TC degradation within 40 min, with a reaction rate constant 41 times higher than that observed with PMS alone. Key operational parameters-including catalyst dosage, PMS concentration, pH, temperature, and the presence of common anions-were systematically optimized, demonstrating the system’s broad applicability for degrading various micropollutants. Radical trapping and EPR analyses identified •O₂⁻ as the dominant reactive species, while the Co²⁺/Co³⁺ and Mo⁴⁺/Mo⁶⁺ redox cycles were found to facilitate continuous PMS activation. Furthermore, four-cycle stability tests confirmed the catalyst’s excellent reusability and potential for practical antibiotic wastewater treatment. This work validates transition metal-doped sulfides as efficient, stable catalysts for antibiotic micropollutant removal via PMS-based advanced oxidation processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cobalt-doped MoS2 PMS activation TC degradation Superoxide radical Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Antibiotic wastewater, primarily originating from mother liquor, washing solutions, and process effluents in pharmaceutical production, is characterized by high organic loading, complex composition, and the presence of recalcitrant substances [1,2]. These substances are resistant to microbial degradation, posing a threat to water quality and ecological balance. Although antibiotics generally exhibit lower direct toxicity than other pharmaceuticals, their structural stability leads to persistent environmental accumulation, which facilitates the proliferation of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and genes, thereby presenting health risks through biomagnification in the food chain [3,4]. Therefore, the development of efficient antibiotic wastewater treatment technologies is of critical importance. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) anchored in peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation have garnered increasing acclaim for their strong oxidation capacity and adaptability across a wide pH range [5–9]. Notably, PMS alone possesses limited oxidative potential to effectively degrade environmental pollutants. The introduction of transition metal ions is widely regarded as one of the most promising strategies for activating PMS through the cleavage of its O-O bond, thereby facilitating the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that significantly enhance the degradation of organic contaminants in aqueous environments [10–13]. Among these metals, low-valent cobalt ions (Co2+) demonstrate the highest catalytic reactivity [14,15]. Nevertheless, under homogeneous reaction conditions, Co2+ catalysts encounter challenges, including metal-induced toxicity and the practical difficulties associated with catalyst recovery and reuse [15–17], which have collectively promoted extensive research efforts aimed at developing efficient Co-based heterogeneous catalysts. Studies have shown that partially incorporating Co2+ into a substrate can significantly enhance its activity and recyclability. For instance, Yu et al. [18] prepared Co-doped ZnO nanocomposites on PET-ITO flexible substrates via hydrothermal methods, achieving a methylene blue (MB) degradation efficiency of 71.36%, surpassing that of pure ZnO. Narayanan et al. [19] synthesized Co2+-doped Fe2O3 nanoparticles through co-precipitation and thermal decomposition, demonstrating that Co2+ doping stabilizes γ-Fe2O3 over α-Fe2O3 at 450 °C, with 5%Co:Fe2O3 exhibiting optimal catalytic activity for paraben rose aniline (PR) degradation. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has emerged as a promising material for environmental remediation due to its unique electronic structure [20–23]. With a band gap of approximately 1.2-1.9 eV and a layered morphology that provides abundant active sites, MoS2 exhibits excellent performance in photocatalytic applications, including water splitting, pollutant degradation, and CO2 reduction [24–27]. Its edge sites, particularly sulfur edges, demonstrate high catalytic activity. MoS2 possesses the intrinsic capability to directly activate PMS through electron transfer occurring between PMS and the Mo(IV)/S-Mo-S active sites [28]. Furthermore, the incorporation of transition metal into the MoS2 lattice not only facilitates enhanced interfacial electron transfer but also modulates its band structure, thereby boosting its efficacy in PMS activation [29]. Our group [30] developed Cu doped MoS2 microspheres as photocatalysts to activate PMS for effective micropollutant degradation, leveraging the redox cycles of Cu2+/Cu+ and Mo6+/Mo4+. Despite the great potential of MoS2 for activating PMS to degrade antibiotics, challenges regarding its stability and practical applications remain, and its performance requires further enhancement. Doping MoS2 with Co2+ is anticipated to enable electronic reconstruction of MoS2 and boost its catalytic activity. In this study, a cobalt-doped MoS2 (Co-MoS2) catalyst was synthesized via a hydrothermal method using preformed MoS2 as the substrate and cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O) as the cobalt source, followed by reduction with sodium borohydride (NaBH4). The composition, structure, morphology, and electrochemical properties of the synthesized Co-MoS2 catalysts were comprehensively characterized. Its catalytic activity was evaluated by activating PMS to degrade tetracycline (TC), a model antibiotic pollutant. The Co-MoS2 catalysts effectively activated PMS, achieving high TC degradation efficiency. The influence of critical parameters (initial PMS/TC concentration, reaction temperature, solution pH, co-existing inorganic anions) on the TC degradation efficiency was systematically investigated. Additionally, both the activity stability and structural stability of the catalysts were evaluated. Drawing upon active species contribution analysis, a comprehensive reaction mechanism for TC degradation within the Co-MoS2/PMS system has been proposed, offering profound insights into the underlying oxidative pathways. This work highlights the promising potential of transition metal-doped sulfide catalysts, particularly the Co-MoS2 system, for efficiently eliminating antibiotic micropollutants via AOPs. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Thiourea (CH4N2S, AR grade) was obtained from McLean Chemical Reagent Co. Anhydrous sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4, 99%), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O, 99%), and sodium borohydride (NaBH4, 99%) were supplied by Aladdin Chemical Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Anhydrous ethanol (C2H5OH, AR grade) was acquired from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). 2.2 Preparation of MoS2 1 g of Na2MoO4 was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized (DI) water to make a solution. Then, 0.60 g of CH4N2S was added, and the mixture was stirred at 700 rpm for 1 h. The resulting mixture was transferred into an autoclave and reacted at 200°C for 12 h. After the reaction, the product was filtered, thoroughly washed, and dried to obtain MoS2. 2.3 Preparation of Co-MoS2 An aqueous solution of MoS2 was prepared by dispersing 200 mg of the prepared MoS2 in 30 mL of DI water, followed by sonication for 30 min. Various amounts of CoCl2·6H2O were then introduced into the suspension, which was subsequently stirred at 600 rpm for 1 h. Afterwards, 0.3 mL of NaBH4 solution (0.5 M) was added dropwise to the mixture under continuous stirring at 600 rpm for another 1 h. The resulting precipitate was collected by filtration, thoroughly washed with DI water, and dried to obtain the xCo-MoS2 sample, where x represents the molar percentage of cobalt incorporated into MoS2. The synthesis process was illustrated in Fig. S1. 2.4 Degradation test TC degradation in the catalyst-activated PMS system was performed under natural pH conditions (pH ∼6.8). In a standard experimental setup, 50 mL of TC solution (20 mg/L) was transferred into a beaker, followed by the addition of 5 mg of xCo-MoS2 catalyst. The mixture was stirred at 600 rpm for 30 min to achieve adsorption saturation. 1 mL of PMS solution (50 mM) was then introduced to initiate the degradation process. At predetermined time intervals (5, 10, 20, 30, and 40 min), 3 mL aliquots were withdrawn, filtered through a 0.22 µm syringe filter, and placed into 5 mL centrifuge tubes. To terminate the reaction and quench any residual PMS, 20 µL of Na2S2O3 solution was added to each sample tube. The entire experiment was conducted in a temperature-controlled water bath maintained at 25 ± 2 °C. The total TC concentration was determined based on the absorbance measured at 357 nm using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer (UV-2600, Shimadzu). All experiments were performed in parallel with a deviation within 5%. 2.5 Characterization methods Comprehensive details concerning the characterization methods were elaborated upon in the Supplementary Information . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The crystal structures and physical phase compositions of MoS2 and xCo-MoS2 were meticulously examined through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, the findings of which are illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). In the case of the MoS2 sample, distinct diffraction peaks observed at 2θ angles of 13.7°, 28.6°, 32.6°, 35.9°, and 58.2° are indicative of the (002), (004), (100), (102), and (110) crystallographic planes of hexagonal MoS2 (PDF#37-1492) [31], respectively. As shown in the figure, the intensity of the (002) peak at 13.7° decreases with increasing cobalt doping levels. This reduction may be attributed to the incorporation of cobalt atoms, which disrupts the structural ordering of MoS2 [32]. In summary, cobalt doping did not alter the fundamental crystalline structure of MoS2, and no additional diffraction peaks related to cobalt or its oxides were observed, suggesting the high purity of the synthesized xCo-MoS2 catalyst. The slight shifts in diffraction peaks with increasing cobalt content indicate that cobalt was successfully incorporated into the MoS2 lattice. As illustrated in Fig. 1(b), the structures of MoS2 and xCo-MoS2 catalysts were further characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy. The results reveal that both MoS2 and xCo-MoS2 exhibit characteristic absorption peaks corresponding to -OH groups at 1642 cm−1, Mo-O bonds at 598 cm−1, and S=O bonds at 907 cm−1 [33], suggesting the presence of partial surface oxidation. Due to the relatively low doping level of cobalt, the FT-IR spectra of xCo-MoS2 are found to be largely consistent with those of pure MoS2. Minor differences in peak positions or intensities are observed across most wavenumbers, indicating that the main structural framework of xCo-MoS2 remains similar to that of MoS2, which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. However, a distinct absorption peak is observed for xCo-MoS2 at 1059 cm−1, which may correspond to Co-S bonds [34]. This finding further supports the successful incorporation of cobalt into the MoS2 matrix and confirms the effective synthesis of the xCo-MoS2 catalyst. The morphologies of MoS2 and 3.0%Co-MoS2 samples were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fig. 2 (a-b ) present the SEM images of the MoS2 sample, which exhibits a spherical structure composed of numerous nanosheets, with sphere diameters ranging from approximately 0.8 to 1.2 μm. As observed in Fig. 2(b), the spherical MoS2 nanosheets grow radially from the center to the periphery, forming a uniform and densely packed porous-like architecture. Fig. 2(c-d) display the SEM images of 3.0%Co-MoS2. After cobalt doping, the spherical structure becomes more compact compared to the pristine MoS2 of similar size, and the individual sphere size is reduced. The original regular spherical structure of MoS2 can still be observed in Fig. 2(d), indicating that the structure has been partially altered but remains largely intact. Fig. S2 shows the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping results of 3.0%Co-MoS2, revealing a uniform distribution of S and Mo elements on the catalyst surface. The presence and homogeneous dispersion of Co confirm its successful incorporation into the MoS2 lattice and even spatial dispersion within the material. The specific surface areas and pore architectures of the samples were investigated through N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis, with detailed data summarized in Table S1. As illustrated in Fig. S3, both the pristine and modified samples exhibit type III isotherms accompanied by H3-type hysteresis loops, confirming the existence of a mesoporous architecture [35]. Such a mesoporous architecture facilitates pollutant diffusion, increases the interaction between the catalyst and contaminants, accelerates catalytic kinetics, and thereby improves degradation efficiency. The average pore size of MoS2 is found to be slightly larger than that of 3.0%Co-MoS2. Moreover, no significant change in the pore type of MoS2 is observed before and after modification, which is consistent with the SEM analysis results. The specific surface area of MoS2 is measured to be 15.4 m2/g, whereas that of 3.0%Co-MoS2 increases to 19.0 m2/g. This enhancement in surface area contributes to the exposure of more active sites, thereby improving the catalytic performance toward pollutant degradation [30], which aligns well with the subsequent electrochemical measurements and activity experiments. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results are presented in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the XPS survey spectrum of 3.0%Co-MoS2 reveals the presence of Mo 3d, S 2p, and Co 2p signals, whereas only Mo 3d and S 2p signals are detected in pure MoS2. The presence of Co 2p signals in 3.0%Co-MoS2 confirms that cobalt has been successfully incorporated into the structure, with no detectable impurity elements present. This finding aligns with the EDS results depicted in Fig. S2. Specifically, the detailed fitting results for Mo 3d are presented in Fig. 3(b). The peak at 236.1 eV corresponds to Mo6+, while the peaks at 228.6 eV, 231.6 eV, and 232.9 eV are assigned to Mo4+ 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbitals, respectively [28,36]. Fig. 3(c) presents the S 2p fitting results. The peaks at 161.4 eV and 162.7 eV correspond to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively [37]. Compared to the Mo 3d and S 2p spectra of pure MoS2, the binding energies of 3.0%Co-MoS2 shift toward higher values, which may be attributed to the interaction between MoS2 and the doped cobalt species [30]. This shift suggests a possible electron transfer effect, which may influence the catalytic properties. It has been reported that lower oxidation states of molybdenum exhibit superior catalytic activity [38], implying that the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst possesses favorable catalytic performance. The Co 2p fitting results are shown in Fig. 3(d). The spectrum confirms the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ species. The main peaks are observed at 782.7 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 798.5 eV (Co 2p1/2), while the satellite peaks appear at 790.6 eV and 806.1 eV (labeled as "sat."). Additionally, the peaks at 786.4 eV and 802.1 eV are attributed to Co2+ 2p3/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2, respectively [39–41]. To further evaluate the electrochemical properties of the samples, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were conducted. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the EIS plots of MoS2 and 3.0%Co-MoS2 reveal that the latter exhibits a smaller semicircle arc radius compared to the former. A smaller arc radius indicates lower electrochemical impedance and enhanced charge transfer capability [42,43], which contributes to the improved TC removal efficiency in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system. The electron transfer behavior among 3.0% Co-MoS2, PMS, and TC was further investigated via LSV, as presented in Fig. 4(b). The current response of 3.0%Co-MoS2 alone is relatively weak. Upon the addition of PMS, a slight increase in current is observed. Notably, a significant enhancement in current occurs after introducing TC, indicating that TC acts as an effective electron donor and plays a crucial role in facilitating charge transfer within the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PM+TC system [44]. Electrochemical surface area (ECSA) measurements were conducted to assess the availability of active sites [45,46]. The ECSA of MoS2 and 3%Co-MoS2 was determined by performing CV tests at varying scan rates (Fig. S4). The double-layer capacitance (Cdl) derived from these CV tests was used to evaluate the ECSA. The ECSA values for MoS2 and 3%Co-MoS2 were found to be 4.58 mF·cm−2 and 7.51 mF·cm−2, respectively (Fig. 4(c)). The increased ECSA suggests a greater number of exposed active sites on 3%Co-MoS2, which contributes to its enhanced catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance and stability The as-prepared Co-MoS2 catalysts were evaluated for their catalytic performance in TC degradation via PMS activation. As illustrated in Fig. 5 (a), control experiments were conducted under various conditions. After 30 min of dark adsorption to achieve equilibrium, it is observed that the TC degradation efficiency by PMS alone is about 6.7%, while the MoS2+PMS system achieves a removal rate of approximately 21.2%. In comparison, the Co-doped MoS2 exhibits significantly enhanced catalytic activity. The degradation efficiency increases with increasing Co content up to a certain level. When the cobalt doping reaches 5.0%, a slight decrease in degradation efficiency is observed. Therefore, 3.0%Co-MoS2 is identified as the optimal catalyst in terms of catalytic performance. Furthermore, the TC removal rate is about 9.2% when 3.0%Co-MoS2 is used without PMS, whereas the removal efficiency increases to as high as 81.5% upon the addition of PMS, highlighting the synergistic effect between the catalyst and PMS. The TC degradation data can be excellently aligned with the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, as presented in Fig. 5(b). The derived rate constants (k) are determined to be 1.0×10−3 min−1 for the PMS system. Notably, the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system exhibits the higher k value of 4.1×10−2 min−1, which is 41 times greater than that of the pristine PMS oxidation process. Compared to previous studies (Table S2), the optimized 3.0%Co-MoS2 demonstrated superior efficiency in the degradation of micropollutants. The mineralization efficiency of organic pollutants serves as a critical indicator for evaluating the overall effectiveness of pollutant treatment processes. To assess the mineralization performance of TC degradation, total organic carbon (TOC) removal was monitored throughout the reaction in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the TOC removal efficiency increases from 18.8% in the MoS2+PMS system to 31.2% in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system. This improvement clearly demonstrates that the incorporation of 3.0%Co significantly enhances the system’s mineralization capacity, highlighting its potential for effective micropollutant removal in wastewater treatment. Furthermore, to comprehensively evaluate the catalytic performance of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst, the degradation efficiencies of various other micropollutants, including oxytetracycline (OTC), carbamazepine (CBZ), ciprofloxacin (CIP), and trimethoprim (TMP), were investigated. As presented in Fig. 5(c), after 40 min of reaction, the degradation efficiencies of OTC, CBZ, CIP, and TMP reach 65.9%, 89.7%, 52.9%, and 40%, respectively. These results indicate that the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst not only effectively activates PMS for TC degradation, but also exhibits strong anti-interference capability and broad applicability in the degradation of diverse organic contaminants. The stability of the catalyst is a critical factor in assessing its degradation efficiency. To evaluate the stability of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst, the reacted sample was rinsed thoroughly with DI water multiple times and subsequently dried at 60°C. The experiment was repeated four times under identical conditions. The results, presented in Fig. 5(d), show TC removal efficiencies of 80.7%, 78%, 70.8%, and 70.5%, respectively. A decrease of approximately 10% in TC degradation efficiency is observed in the fourth cycle compared to the first, which can be attributed to the gradual coverage or blocking of active sites on the catalyst surface during repeated use, thereby reducing the available surface area for reaction [47]. The cycling experiments illustrated the good recyclability of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis revealed that the cobalt content in the solution after cycling was as low as 1.4%, indicating the stability of the Co species in 3.0%Co-MoS2. To further examine the structural stability, FT-IR and XRD characterizations were conducted on the 3.0%Co-MoS2 sample recovered after four cycles, as shown in Fig. S6. No significant changes are observed in the crystal structure, chemical bonding, or vibrational characteristics of functional groups. The morphology of the used 3.0%Co-MoS2 sample was also characterized. As shown in Fig. S7, the morphology remains unchanged after the reaction. These results indicate that the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst maintains its structure integrity and chemical stability throughout the cycling process. These results further confirm the robustness and excellent structural stability of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst, along with its sustained catalytic activity. 3.3 Optimization of reaction parameters The influences of various parameters, such as catalyst dosage, TC concentration, PMS concentration, solution pH, reaction temperature, and the presence of anions, on the degradation of TC by the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system were systematically explored. As illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), the TC removal efficiency increases from 61.3% to 88.8% when the catalyst dosage is raised from 0.02 g/L to 0.2 g/L. This improvement can be attributed to the increased number of active sites available in the reaction system, which facilitated the generation of more active species [48]. However, it is noteworthy that the rate of enhancement in TC degradation slows significantly when the catalyst dosage exceeds 0.1 g/L. Fig. 6(b) illustrates the influence of initial TC concentration on the degradation efficiency. When the TC concentration is 10 mg/L, nearly complete removal (approximately 100%) is achieved, indicating highly effective degradation. However, as the initial TC concentration increases, the removal efficiency gradually decreases to approximately 61.2%. This decline may be due to competitive adsorption between residual TC molecules and intermediate products for the limited reactive active sites, thereby reducing the interaction between TC and reactive species. Additionally, higher TC concentrations may lead to increased consumption of intermediates by reactive species, further lowering the overall degradation efficiency [35]. Fig. 6(c) presents the effect of varying PMS dosages on the degradation efficiency of TC. The results indicate that increasing the PMS concentration from 0.2 mM to 2.0 mM leads to an improvement in TC degradation efficiency, rising from 62.2% to 83.5%. This trend can be attributed to the enhanced availability of reactive species resulting from increased PMS dosage, which facilitates greater interaction with active sites on the surface of the 3.0% Co-MoS2 catalyst. Consequently, with a balance between efficacy and economic feasibility, a catalyst dosage of 0.1 g/L, 1.0 mM PMS, and 20 mg/L TC were established as the optimal experimental condition for all ensuing investigations. pH is widely recognized as a critical parameter influencing the activation of PMS for micropollutant degradation [49]. The influence of pH on TC degradation was investigated under acidic (pH 4.0), neutral (pH 6.8), and alkaline (pH 9.2) conditions, as shown in Fig. 6(d). At pH 4.0, the TC degradation efficiency is relatively low at approximately 40%, likely due to the predominance of H2SO5 over HSO5 −, which restricts the decomposition of PMS and consequently limits radical generation [50]. In contrast, the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst exhibited satisfactory degradation efficiencies at both pH 6.80 and pH 9.2, indicating its effectiveness across a broad pH range. As shown in Fig. S8(a, b), the TC degradation efficiencies achieved by the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst at reaction temperatures of 15°C, 25°C, 35°C, and 45°C are 63.3%, 80.3%, 85.6%, and 90.1%, respectively. The degradation efficiency of TC increases with rising temperature, indicating that reaction temperature plays a crucial role in the activation of PMS within this system. Notably, the increase in temperature from 15 °C to 45 °C significantly accelerates the reaction rate during the first 5 min. This may be attributed to the enhanced cleavage of the O-O bond in PMS under higher temperatures, which facilitates rapid activation of PMS and thereby improves TC degradation efficiency. Furthermore, by analyzing the effect of reaction temperature on TC degradation before and after Co modification, the activation energy (Ea) was calculated using the Arrhenius equation (Fig. S8(c, d)). The Ea for the MoS2+PMS system is determined to be 26.86 kJ/mol, whereas that for the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system is significantly lower at 7.6 kJ/mol. A lower activation energy indicates a more facile reaction process [51]. To minimize the influence of temperature variation, all experiments were conducted at a controlled temperature of 25 ± 2°C. Various anions are commonly present in natural water systems. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate their influence on TC degradation within the reaction system. The effects of four representative anions, including Cl−, NO3 −, SO4 2−, and H2PO4 −, on TC degradation efficiency were investigated at different concentrations. Fig. S9(a) presents the impact of varying Cl− concentrations on the TC degradation performance of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst. The addition of Cl− exhibits a noticeable inhibitory effect, with the final degradation efficiency decreasing as the Cl− concentration increases. This phenomenon may be attributed to the competitive reactions between Cl− and reactive species such as SO4 •−, and •OH, leading to the formation of chlorine-containing radicals with relatively lower redox potentials [52]. As shown in Fig. S9(b, c), both NO3 − and SO4 2− have minimal effects on TC removal, suggesting that these anions do not significantly interfere with the catalytic process. In contrast, as depicted in Fig. S9(d), increasing the concentration of H2PO4 − results in an improvement in TC degradation efficiency. This enhancement may be due to the formation of additional active sites on the surface of the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst induced by H2PO4 −, which enhances the adsorption capacity for TC and thereby promotes its degradation [53]. Furthermore, the influence of dissolved organic matter, specifically humic acid (HA), on TC degradation was explored. As depicted in Fig. S10, HA exhibits a significant promoting effect on TC degradation, which can be attributed the increased production of reactive oxygen species facilitated by HA [54,55]. 3.4 Reactive oxidation species The contribution of active species involved in TC degradation in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system was investigated by introducing various radical scavengers into the reaction solution. The experimental results are presented in Fig. 7 (a). In this study, TBA, MeOH, AA, and L-Histidine were selected as scavengers for •OH, SO4 •−, •O2 −, and 1O2 radicals, respectively [13,56]. Specifically, TBA can effectively scavenge •OH radicals, MeOH can scavenge both •OH and SO4 •− radicals, AA is capable of scavenging •O2 − radicals, and L-Histidine reacts selectively with 1O2 [57]. After adding these scavengers to the reaction system, the degradation efficiencies of TC after 40 min are 62.7%, 51.6%, 10.6%, and 10.7%, respectively. These results indicate that •O2 − plays the most significant role in TC degradation. Based on the inhibition effects observed, the relative contributions of reactive species to TC degradation are ranked as follows: •O2 −>1O2> SO4 •−> •OH. To unequivocally identify the specific reactive oxygen species generated in the system, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis was conducted (Fig. 7(b-d)). Using DMPO as a trapping agent in an aqueous medium, the EPR signals corresponding to •OH radicals are detected, while no signal for SO4 •− is observed under pure PMS conditions. However, in the presence of 3.0%Co-MoS2 and PMS, both SO4 •− and •OH signals are detected with significantly enhanced intensity (fig. 7(c)). For the detection of •O2 −, DMPO was used as the spin trap in methanol. As shown in Fig. 7(b), no •O2 − signal is observed when PMS is used alone. In contrast, four distinct characteristic peaks corresponding to DMPO-•O2 − adducts are observed upon the addition of 3.0%Co-MoS2 and PMS, confirming the generation of •O2 − in this system. This finding is consistent with the results from the scavenging experiments. Additionally, TEMP was utilized as a trapping agent for 1O2 in aqueous solution. As displayed in Fig. 7(d), a weak 1:1:1 triplet EPR signal of 1O2 is detected with PMS alone, whereas a significantly enhanced 1O2 signal is observed in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS system, indicating that 3.0%Co-MoS2 effectively activates PMS to generate 1O2. 3.5 Reaction mechanism Combined with radical trapping experiments and EPR analysis, the degradation of TC by 3.0%Co-MoS2-activated PMS involved both free radicals (•O2 −, SO4 •−, •OH) and non-radical species (1O2). These active species are generated through the decomposition of HSO5 −, which produces SO5 2− and H+ ions. Subsequently, SO5 2− reacts with H2O to form •O2 − radicals. The subsequent transformation of •O2 − leads to the generation of SO4 •−, 1O2, and •OH [58]. Among these reactive species, •O2 − played a dominant role, while SO4 •− and 1O2 had minor contributions, and •OH exhibited negligible activity. Based on the above results and discussions, a plausible reaction mechanism for TC degradation via PMS activation by the 3.0%Co-MoS2 catalyst was proposed as Fig. 8 . Firstly, as revealed by XPS analysis, the distinct valence states of cobalt and molybdenum present on the surface of 3.0%Co-MoS2 indicate that both Co2+ and Mo4+ are capable of activating PMS to produce SO4 •− radicals, which are subsequently oxidized back to their higher oxidation states, Co3+ and Mo6+ (Eqs. 1-4). It is this Co2+/Co3+ and Mo6+/Mo4+ redox cycling that promotes the continuous and accelerated generation of large quantities of free radicals and enhances the efficient activation of PMS. Secondly, SO4 •− reacted with OH− to produce •OH radicals (Eq. 5), while SO5 •− can react with H2O to generate •OH radicals (Eq. 6). HSO5 − could also decompose into SO5 2− and H+, followed by a reaction between SO5 2− and H2O to generate •O2 − radicals [58] (Eqs. 7, 8). Additionally, a portion of the generated •O2 − radicals could further react with •OH to form 1O2 (Eq. 9). Finally, in the 3.0%Co-MoS2+PMS catalytic system, TC was efficiently degraded into small molecules, CO2, and H2O through the synergistic action of •O2 −, •OH, SO4 •−, and 1O2 (Eq. 10). (1) ≡ C o 2 + + HS O 5 − → ≡ C o 3 + + S O 4 · − + O H − (2) ≡ C o 3 + + HS O 5 − → ≡ C o 2 + + S O 5 · − + H + (3) ≡ M o 4 + + 2 HS O 5 − → 2 S O 4 · − + ≡ M o 6 + + 2 O H − (4) ≡ M o 6 + + 2 HS O 5 − → S O 5 · − + ≡ M o 4 + + 2 H + (5) S O 4 · − + O H − → · OH + S O 4 2 − (6) S O 5 · − + H 2 O → · OH + S O 4 2 − (7) HS O 5 − → S O 5 2 − + H + (8) S O 5 2 − + H 2 O → · O 2 − + S O 4 2 − + H + (9) · O 2 − + · OH → 1 O 2 + O H − (10) ( · O 2 − / S O 4 · − / 1 O 2 / · OH ) + TC → Intermediates + C O 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusion Co-MoS2 catalysts were successfully prepared through a one-step hydrothermal method. The resulting material features a compact spherical morphology, an increased specific surface area, and enhanced electron transfer capability, as evidenced by XRD, SEM, and EIS analyses. The 3.0%Co-MoS2/PMS system demonstrates superior TC degradation efficiency, significantly outperforming both pure MoS2/PMS and PMS alone. Notably, the Co-MoS2/PMS system maintains high performance across a wide pH range, shows minimal interference from common anions, and effectively degrades diverse micropollutants, thereby indicating broad environmental applicability. Radical scavenging experiments and EPR analysis reveal that PMS activation by Co-MoS2 generates •O2 −, SO4 •−, •OH, and 1O2, with •O2 − playing the dominant role. The continuous regeneration of Co²⁺/Co³⁺ and Mo⁴⁺/Mo⁶⁺ redox couples facilitates sustained radical production, driving efficient TC degradation. This work provides a promising strategy for developing transition metal-doped sulfide catalysts in advanced oxidation processes for environmental remediation. coredata.dc:description: Antibiotic wastewater poses significant environmental risks due to the persistent micropollutants such as tetracycline (TC), which contribute to the development of antibiotic resistance. In this study, cobalt-doped molybdenum disulfide (Co-MoS₂) catalysts were synthesized via the hydrothermal method to enhance peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation for efficient TC degradation. Comprehensive material characterizations (XRD, FT-IR, SEM, XPS) confirmed the successful incorporation of Co into the MoS2 lattice, resulting in a mesoporous structure with an increased specific surface area, improved charge transfer efficiency, and greater exposure of active sites. Under optimal conditions, the 3.0%Co-MoS₂ catalyst achieved 81.5% TC degradation within 40 min, with a reaction rate constant 41 times higher than that observed with PMS alone. Key operational parameters-including catalyst dosage, PMS concentration, pH, temperature, and the presence of common anions-were systematically optimized, demonstrating the system’s broad applicability for degrading various micropollutants. Radical trapping and EPR analyses identified •O₂⁻ as the dominant reactive species, while the Co²⁺/Co³⁺ and Mo⁴⁺/Mo⁶⁺ redox cycles were found to facilitate continuous PMS activation. Furthermore, four-cycle stability tests confirmed the catalyst’s excellent reusability and potential for practical antibiotic wastewater treatment. This work validates transition metal-doped sulfides as efficient, stable catalysts for antibiotic micropollutant removal via PMS-based advanced oxidation processes.
